metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Git Tagging
Key Commands for Tagging
What is a Tag?
A tag in Git is like a label or bookmark for a specific commit.
content.html: A tag in Git is like a label or bookmark for a specific commit.

content.text: Tags are most often used to mark important points in your project history, like releases ( v1.0 or v2.0 ).
content.html: Tags are most often used to mark important points in your project history, like releases (v1.0 or v2.0).

content.text: Tags are a simple and reliable way to keep track of versions and share them with your team or users.
content.html: Tags are a simple and reliable way to keep track of versions and share them with your team or users.

content.text: Some common tag types include:
content.html: Some common tag types include:

content.text: Create a Lightweight Tag
A lightweight tag is just a name for a commit.
content.html: A lightweight tag is just a name for a commit.

content.text: It's quick and simple, but does not store extra information.
content.html: It's quick and simple, but does not store extra information.

content.text: Annotated vs Lightweight Tags

content.code_html: git tag v1.0

content.text: Create an Annotated Tag ( -a -m )
An annotated tag stores your name, the date, and a message.
content.html: An annotated tag stores your name, the date, and a message.

content.text: This is recommended for most uses.
content.html: This is recommended for most uses.

content.code_html: git tag -a v1.0 -m "Version 1.0 release"

content.text: Tag a Specific Commit
You can tag an older commit by specifying its hash:
content.html: You can tag an older commit by specifying its hash:

content.code_html: git tag v1.1 1a2b3c4d

content.text: Replace 1a2b3c4d with the commit hash you want to tag.
content.html: Replace 1a2b3c4d with the commit hash you want to tag.

content.text: List Tags
See all tags in your repository:
content.html: See all tags in your repository:

content.code_html: git tag

content.text: Show Tag Details ( git show )
See details about a tag and the commit it points to:
content.html: See details about a tag and the commit it points to:

content.code_html: git show v1.0

content.text: Push Tags to Remote
By default, tags exist only on your local computer.
content.html: By default, tags exist only on your local computer.

content.text: If you want others to see your tags, you need to push them to your remote repository.
content.html: If you want others to see your tags, you need to push them to your remote repository.

content.text: If you don't push your tags, only you will see them, and only locally.
content.html: If you don't push your tags, only you will see them, and only locally.

content.text: To push a single tag to your remote repository (for example, after creating a release tag):
content.html: To push a single tag to your remote repository (for example, after creating a release tag):

content.code_html: git push origin v1.0

content.text: Did you know? Pushing commits with git push does not push your tags!
content.html: Did you know? Pushing commits with git push does not push your tags!

content.text: You must push tags explicitly as shown above.
content.html: You must push tags explicitly as shown above.

content.text: To push all your local tags to the remote at once (useful if you've created several tags):
content.html: To push all your local tags to the remote at once (useful if you've created several tags):

content.code_html: git push --tags

content.text: Delete Tags
Delete a tag locally:
content.html: Delete a tag locally:

content.code_html: git tag -d v1.0

content.text: Delete a tag from the remote repository:
content.html: Delete a tag from the remote repository:

content.code_html: git push origin --delete tag v1.0

content.text: Update or Replace a Tag (Force Push)
If you need to move a tag to a different commit and update the remote, use --force :
content.html: If you need to move a tag to a different commit and update the remote, use --force:

content.code:
git
tag -f v1.0
<
new-commit-hash
>


git
push --force origin v1.0
content.code_html:
git tag -f v1.0 <new-commit-hash>
git push --force origin v1.0

content.text: Tagging Best Practices
Troubleshooting
